awd_titl_txt: Bridging Mechanics and Electrochemistry: Theories and Experiments on Battery Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
Mechanical issues are ubiquitous in energy storage, conversion, and harvesting. In rechargeable batteries, which are a key enabler of portable electronics and electrification of automotive transportation, mechanical degradation compromises the performance of current technology and limits the implementation of next-generation high-capacity energy materials. This project seeks to describe the aging mechanisms in batteries, which would also facilitate the development of energy storage materials with enhanced mechanical reliability. This will be achieved through a focus on understanding the fundamental coupling between mechanical forces and electrochemistry or energy storage performance via a close integration of theoretical modeling and experimental characterizations. The outcome of this research will have a broad impact on diverse sectors of the industry, from wearable electronics to electric cars. On the education front, the project will create opportunities to train graduate students in the complex sciences of electrochemistry and mechanics as well as educate students in the mechanics of energy storage materials. The outreach activities will also enhance an existing collaboration with the Women in Engineering program at Purdue to encourage participation of female students in engineering sciences.

The overarching goal of this project is to unravel the fundamental coupling between mechanics and electrochemistry using integrated theories and experiments on battery materials.  Research effort include formulating a theory of stress-modulated electron transfer and ion diffusion to understand the effects on energy capacity. Similarly, the continuum theory of stress-composition-reaction coupling will lay a foundation for understanding how mechanical stress modulates the electrochemical processes and how the latter mediates failure and aging of energy materials. The computational modeling of heterogeneous structures in batteries will advance the understanding of stress-regulated kinetics and capacity. The experiments will use energy harvester devices and solid-state batteries in conjunction with a novel electrochemical nano-indenter and coupons based on mechanical testing standards to provide data for the validation of the continuum theories.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the research project is to unravel the fundamental coupling between mechanics and electrochemistry in battery materials using integrated theories and experiments. The research tasks include (i) formulating the kinetics of stress regulated electron transfer and ion transport; using the mechanical energy harvester device to validate the theory and to identify the competition between diffusion controlled versus electron transfer limited regimes, (ii) formulating the yield condition and rheology model for a material subject to concurrent mechanical stresses and chemical driving force of reactions; using the home-developed in-situ nanoindentation to validate the theory of reactive flow, (iii) formulating a theory of Li assisted corrosive fracture; conducting bending experiments loaded by indentation in inert environment to capture the dynamics of crack growth in lithiated phases, and (iv) employing the reconstructed 3D composite models in real batteries to investigate the influence of mechanical stresses on the capacity of batteries; performing experiments to quantitatively measure the effect of stresses on the capacity and potential of batteries.

In response to NSF DCL 20-027, "Data Science Activities for the Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation Communities", the PI received a supplement fund in 2020 to expand the project by implementing the data science approaches. The research activities include (i) creating database of informatics of the morphological features and atomistic fingerprint from nanoscale active particles to mesoscale particle assembles in the composite electrodes of Li-ion batteries, (ii) using supervised/unsupervised/hybrid data mining methods to determine statistically significant heterogeneity of redox reactions, stress, and mechanical failure, and (iii) using the data-driven approach to understand the holistic behavior of mechanics and electrochemistry in batteries.

The planned research tasks were carried out in the past over four years. The outcome includes 14 peer-reviewed journal papers and one US patent. The research output was presented and disseminated in 8 academic conferences. The educational activities associated with this project include training graduate and undergraduate students on interdisciplinary skills of mechanics, electrochemistry, and material science, curriculum development of mechanics of energy materials for a graduate-level course, and hands-on outreach activities for middle school students on battery technology coordinated through the Women in Engineering program at Purdue University. Through this research project, Luize Scalco de Vasconcelos completed her PhD thesis of “Chemo-mechanics of Li-ion Batteries: In-situ and Operando Studies”. The PI has developed a new graduate course of Solid Mechanics at Purdue, in which the chemical strain and mechanical failure in battery materials is an important module of this course. The PI and the research group participated in the outreach activities to middle/elementary school students organized by the Women in Engineering Program at Purdue twice.

On the intellectual merit, the emergence of the multiple physics promotes new understanding in mechanics. The kinetics of diffusive and interfacial reactions in batteries induce and couple with such rich mechanics as large elasto-plastic deformation, reactive plasticity, cavitation, and corrosive fracture. The continuum theories of stress-composition-reaction coupling lays a foundation for understanding how mechanical stress modulates the electrochemical processes and how the latter mediates failure and aging of battery materials. The computational program applied for heterogeneous structures advances the understanding of stress-regulated kinetics and capacity in real batteries. The experiment using in-situ nanoindentation is unique to validate the continuum theories. The research draws a complete spectrum of the impact of mechanics on electrochemical processes, including mass transport, charge transfer, reactive flow, corrosive fracture, and capacity of real batteries.

On the broader impact, this project creates knowledge on the fundamental coupling between mechanics and electrochemistry via a close integration of theoretical and experimental approaches. Such knowledge is crucial to elucidating the aging mechanisms of batteries which in turn will synergistically contribute to the development of materials of enhanced mechanical reliability. Bridging the interdisciplinary field of mechanics and electrochemistry with a focus of energy solutions can be truly rewarding for the fundamental science as well as technologies in large-scale applications. On the education front, the project supports one female student to finish her PhD thesis, another female student for one year to implement the data science approach in her PhD thesis, and five undergraduate students were trained with each in the PI’s group for more than two semesters. This project creates exciting opportunities to educate students on the myriad applications of mechanics in energy materials. The outreach activities also enhance an existing collaboration with the Women in Engineering at Purdue and promotes the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering sciences.


Last Modified: 12/04/2022
Modified by: Kejie Zhao
